Other Concerns || Does Modal Fictionalism Deliver Possible Worlds Semantics?
4.6 Three More Concerns

Modal fictionalism has attracted a range of other objections and
concerns. Some of these can be generalised to other fictionalist
projects; some generalise to other approaches to possible worlds; and
some seem to rely on specific features of modal fictionalist
proposals. Rather than trying to describe each controversy in detail,
I will briefly outline three with some references for those who wish
to track down the relevant
 literature.[8]

The Threat from Abstractionism: Fictionalists seem to
need fictions, in the sense of stories or story-like entities. Some
realists about possible worlds treat possible worlds themselves as
representational entities of the same general sort that fictions seem
to be: these theorists are “abstractionists” in the
terminology of van Inwagen 1986, or “ersatzers” in the
terminology of Lewis 1986. Abstractionists may take worlds to be
constructions out of sentences, or perhaps more commonly identify
worlds with maximal propositions or with constructions out of
propositions (e.g. sets of propositions). Once we have representations
that are rich enough to represent every possibility, fictionalists
need to explain why they prefer to be be fictionalists rather than
identifying possible worlds with the appropriate representations.

Abstractionist realism seems more straightforward than fictionalism in
a number of ways, so fictionalists, particularly platonist
fictionalists, risk being victims of their own success and collapsing
into a kind of realism. (Nolan 1997a p 272 mentions this worry.) Rosen
1990, particulary on pp 328–9, mentions some motivations for a
fictionalist to not be an abstractionist. Turp 2011 discusses a
similar challenge: on many accounts of the ontology of fiction,
fictional worlds would themselves be some sort of existing abstract
object, of the sort that a fictionalist who wishes to reject
abstractionism seems committed to rejecting. Finally, Dombrovszki 2017
endorses the existence of the possible worlds postulated by a modal
fiction: in his “hybrid modal fiction” possible worlds are
creatures of fiction but nevertheless exist (much as so-called
“fictional realists” hold that Sherlock Holmes is a
fictional object that exists). If Dombrovszki is right, this is not so
much a threat from abstractionism as an opportunity to be a modal
fictionalist and a realist about possible worlds at the same time.

Concern About Concern: Rosen 1990 (pp 349–354)
discusses an “argument for concern” against modal
fictionalism, analogous to an argument from concern famously offered
by Saul Kripke against David Lewis’s counterpart theory. (Kripke
1980 p 45) Hubert Humphrey, upon losing an election, cares that he
could have won. On the face of it, he does not care that someone like
him elsewhere in reality does win. Yet according to David
Lewis’s analysis of what it is for Humphrey to have possibly
won, his possibly winning amounts to a “counterpart” of
Humphrey winning a (counterpart) election in another possible
world.

Likewise, Humphrey presumably does not care very much whether a
special story about him claims that he wins in an alternative
universe. Rosen, along with many other philosophers, thinks that this
would not directly show there was any problem with a theory that
accounted for the possibility of Humphrey winning in terms of the
goings-on in another concrete universe, or the contents of a
distinctive fiction: Humphrey might care about a fact without
realising what the analysis of that fact involves (Rosen 1990 p 349).
Rosen instead suggests there may be a “pragmatic” cost to
the view: those who come to accept it may have to revise substantially
what they care about, either by caring more about the goings-on of a
story, or less about what could have happened. There is also the
question of why we should care about what happens in any of the
plausible candidate fictions: this perhaps touches on the question of
choosing a fiction discussed in 4.3, above.

Lewis 1986 pp 195–197 argues that a version of the argument from
concern can be at least raised about any realist possible worlds
theory account of possibility: and, he would likely add, any
fictionalist account as well. If Humphrey is unfamiliar with
possible-worlds-jargon, he may not take himself to have any concern
with possible worlds when it hurts that he could have won. Of course,
theorists may wish to offer reasons why some accounts do better in
respecting the facts about what we are concerned with than others. (Or
indeed give general reasons why no argument from concern is a
challenge to theories of possibility.)

About Aboutness: Armour-Garb (2015, 1212–1218)
raises a concern for a modal fictionalist seeking an “elliptical
rendering” of modal claims in terms of a claim about what is true
according to a fiction of possible worlds. It is that the modal claims
we begin with are not about the same things as the paraphrases in
terms of a fiction of possible worlds. For example, instead of the claim that possibly, there are blue swans, which seems to be about swans and their color, we in effect get a claim about a fiction (we get a claim that means “according to MF, there are blue swans in a possible world”). 
 This is a problem, according to
Armour-Garb, because the point of modal claims involves them being
about the things they normally seem to be about, so the modal
fictionalist’s substitute is inadequate. A theorist could, of
course, endorse the fictionalist biconditional without thinking that
modal claims are about a fiction of worlds at all. Rosen 1990 does
talk, in the case of strong modal fictionalism, of an
“analysis” of modal claims in terms of claims about what
is true according to the modal fiction, so modal fictionalists who
want to follow him in this need to be clear about whether they think
this analysis gives the meaning of the modal claims they use. And if
the analysis is intended to give the meaning of modal expressions, they should make clear why
it does not change the subject from what we took ourselves to be
saying all along.
